newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast crudes slide late with NYMEX, diffs.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast crudes slide late with NYMEX, diffs.

text.p: U.S. West Coast light crude prices slid late Friday, tracking a slump in NYMEX prices and falling differentials for Alaska North Slope.
Outright prices for ANS crude dipped 60 cents below Thursday levels to $22.05/22.35 a barrel. WTI fell on news that Iraq would suspend strikes against U.S. warplanes patrolling "no-fly zones."
Traders reacted cautiously to news late Friday that the U.S. would send 5,000 troops to Kuwait as part of a build-up in the Persian Gulf. They will join 1,200 troops stationed there since August.
"Most traders went home (Friday) thinking the situation had been diffused," one after-hours trader said. "But that's the thinking we all had a week ago."
Light grades in California were poised for further falls late, after BP, a major ANS producer, lowered its sale price by five cents Thursday.
BP sold a full cargo to Chevron Thursday at $2.30 a barrel under October WTI.
And news of crowded storage tanks at the Port of Valdez prompted the Trans-Alaska pipeline to slow throughput by 30 percent early Thursday, traders said.
Another light grade, Line 63, saw its discounts unchanged at WTI minus $2.60/2.50 a barrel.
Prenominations are due to start mid-week and outright values for the grade were $21.85/22.05, down about 40 cents from Thursday.
California heavy grades were flat late after rising Thursday on increased posted prices.
Discounts for Kern River were 50/25 cents under postings, with supplies seen tightening as refineries ran more of the grades.
Greater consumption of heavies came after recent posted prices changes pushed up light grades more steeply than heavies, making the grade more appealing to buy.
Kern River values ranged $15.60/15.90 a barrel, compared to light grade levels in the low $20s.
